story:
Why contribute? 

World Can't Wait-Hawai`i is the Honolulu chapter of the national World Can't Wait organization. It's mission is to take action, regardless of which political party holds power, to expose the crimes of the U.S. Government, and to put humanity and the planet first.   

Today the Trump/Pence regime is putting humanity and the planet in peril and the only way to stop them is to build a movement that is strong enough to bring millions of people into the streets, declaring this whole regime is illegitimate and demanding, and not stopping, until the Trump/Pence Regime Is Driven from Power.  

World Can't Wait-Hawai`i works closely with Refuse Fascism  and is determined to do whatever it can to build the strongest possible movement against Trump's fascist agenda.    Trump's environmental policies, his expansion of the military, and his threats to use nukes threaten our very lives.

To accomplish what needs to be done we need funds.  World Can't Wait scrapes and scrounges but still needs money for paints, bullhorns, venue rentals, fabric and banner material, palm cards and leaflets, and much more.  Contribute what you can, whether that's $5 or $100.
story_txt: Why contribute? World Can't Wait-Hawai`i is the Honolulu chapter of the national World Can't Wait organization. It's mission is to take action, regardless of which political party holds power, to expose the crimes of the U.S. Government, and to put humanity and the planet first.   Today the Trump/Pence regime is putting humanity and the planet in peril and the only way to stop them is to build a movement that is strong enough to bring millions of people into the streets, declaring this whole regime is illegitimate and demanding, and not stopping, until the Trump/Pence Regime Is Driven from Power.  World Can't Wait-Hawai`i works closely with Refuse Fascism  and is determined to do whatever it can to build the strongest possible movement against Trump's fascist agenda.    Trump's environmental policies, his expansion of the military, and his threats to use nukes threaten our very lives.To accomplish what needs to be done we need funds.  World Can't Wait scrapes and scrounges but still needs money for paints, bullhorns, venue rentals, fabric and banner material, palm cards and leaflets, and much more.  Contribute what you can, whether that's $5 or $100.

story:
We will be traveling to Haiti on January 10th 2013 for a week with a group of 14 people from Journey Commnity Church.   While we are there we will be doing the following.....

- Visit a local church that our group (Journey Community Church) helps support and be an encouragement to the people of the congregation.  

- Visit the local medical clinic that Journey Church opened there and deliver supplies to help the clinic to continue its assistance to the local people.

- Visit tent city where we will provide minor medical aid and also talk and pray with the people there.  These people were hit hardest by the earthquake and live amongst garbage in tents. 

- Visit local orphanages where we will bring food and also just to love on these kids and put smiles on their faces!! :-)

Please help us to get there!! We have already raised $900 of the $2500 we need.  Every little bit helps!! 

Thank you so much for your support!!

Kristen & Brandon

story:
Who We Are

Our Mission: Northwest Earth Institute is a non-profit organization that inspires people to take responsibility for Earth.

We believe change should be fun. There’s no shortage of information about the serious challenges facing our planet – and although most people say they would like to do more, they don’t know where to start.

That’s where we come in. For 20 years, NWEI has helped make change more possible, more social, and yes, more fun by helping people connect with their communities and take action, together. 

About This Campaign

At the core of our work are discussion courses (like the one we are asking to you to fund today!) that give communities a non-prescriptive framework to take action on issues that matter. Building on our work to advance sustainability and a brighter future at the grassroots level, we turn this spring to tackle the interrelated social issues facing our world. 

Heading toward 9 billion people on planet Earth with the fewest regrets demands a holistic approach. To act for global prosperity, we need to fully understand the complex systems that impact our everyday decisions. 

Through shared learning and discovery, the NW Earth Institute’s newest discussion course, Seeing Systems: Peace, Justice & Sustainability, empowers individuals and communities to create real change in their daily lives, contributing to a more peaceful, just and sustainable world. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Every single dollar we raise will go directly toward the publication and distribution of our new discussion course book, available for pre-order now! 
  • While we might not have the most exciting perks in the world, yours is an investment that creates real change in communities throughout the country. It's something you can feel good about -- and something you have a direct stake in.

The Impact

Before the term "sustainability" was embedded in our culture, the NW Earth Institute was building a foundation of civic engagement and community transformation. Every dollar we raise here is put toward not just the funding of a vital educational tool, but toward an education that takes us into the depth of things. A depth that’s needed more than ever before. Over 145,000 people have participated in NW Earth Institute programs, and local business, higher education and community leaders reference NWEI as a vehicle for positive change.

You know that Margaret Mead quote?

"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has."

However cliche it may seem, its truth remains. Whether you're looking at the civil rights movement of the '60s or the cultural shift to respond to the real risks of climate change, never doubt that your community can be the change you want to see in the world.*

(*Alright, we admit to referencing Gandhi in that one, too.) 

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey, we're a nonprofit -- there are are many ways you can get involved and help! We understand that you might not have cash to contribute. But don't go! Here are some impactful ways in which you can still help:

  • Make some noise about our campaign! Personal emails, Facebook, Twitter -- it's all good! Share this campaign widely -- peace and justice touch us all and perhaps someone in your network would like to support the cause!
  • Still curious? Email danny@nwei.org, and let's talk about ways to get involved.

story:
Imagine being unable to jump in your car or hop on the bus to get to an important doctor's appointment. What if you had no way to go see potential apartments?  What if you were told to move your belongings out of storage by tomorrow, or lose them forever?

The 200 frail and homeless seniors we serve everyday at Senior Support Services don't have to imagine.  It's what they experience all the time. 

We are excited to announce that a generous donor has given us a Nissan Pathfinder, christened "Stella".  Stella will allow us to safely escort our clients to critical appointments and provide immediate assistance in relocation.

We just need a little push to get Stella on her path to transporting homeless seniors!

What it will take:

$1350 for one year of car insurance

$250 for car registration

$400 for the "keep Stella running" fund

--------

$2,000 Total

story:
What is this about?

https://www.facebook.com/groups/calaisaidfromsomerset/

email: calaisaidfromsomerset@groups.facebook.com

I'm sure you have seen the recent news coverage regarding the situation and are aware of the humanitarian crisis less than 30 miles from British shores.

We are a growing group of individuals coming together to support our fellow human-beings currently living in what's been described by volunteers on the ground as a 'humanitarian- disaster'.

There are up to 4,000 people living in squalid conditions in Calais, mostly men but including women, young children and some with serious medical requirements.

We are collecting emergency supplies for basic survival to deliver on October 24th:

  • Food
  • Shelter - Tents, Sleeping bags, Blankets
  • Clothing & Shoes
  • Sanitary Supplies

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising money that will cover our transportation costs - van, ferry & fuel. We estimate this will be in the region of £400 in total.

All excess funds will be used to buy supplies that we will deliver to local charities working directly with the camp refugees on the ground.

As the situation on the ground is a volatile and rapidly changing environment we will be liaising directly with the local organisations who work directly with refugees to ensure that the supplies we are bringing are the most needed at that time.

Local organisations are: 

http://www.laubergedesmigrants.fr and http://www.secours-catholique.org

The Impact

As the winter approaches the difference warmth, shelter and food (basic survival needs that most of us take for granted) could be literally life-saving for some people. 

The only protections from the elements are tents and improvised shelters constructed from pallets and tarpaulin, some of which sleep up to 40 at a time. Winter is just around the corner and volunteers are increasingly concerned about the lack of men's shoes, warm clothing and sleeping bags.

Those in the camp are forced to rely on charity for their survival but resources are stretched to breaking point. A makeshift hospital in the camp treats up to 90 people a day, some with serious injuries. Medical supplies are desperately low.

Every day those of the camp’s residents who are able to do so visit the Jules Ferry day centre in hope of receiving one of the government funded free meals. Some queue from 11am until 6pm; however there is only enough food for 2,000 people and countless leave empty handed.

Many of the refugees are malnourished.

The U.N. has described the situation in Calais as a "Civil Emergency" and called for a “comprehensive package and.... a sustainable response.” Sadly this is not forthcoming and the day to day lives of those in the camps is in the hands of volunteers and the generosity of people such as you.

Risks & Challenges

The situation in Calais is volatile and rapidly changing, we are staying in contact with local aid organisations to ensure that the money we collect can be used to buy the most appropriate and useful supplies needed at the time.

If for any reason we are unable to make our journey due to political/legal changes that impact the borders and the camp we will donate any funds collected directly to the organisations working with refugees in Calais.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate you may not be able to donate financially so other ways you can help are:

  • Donations of items on our list at: https://www.facebook.com/groups/calaisaidfromsomerset/
  • Volunteer to help with sorting/packing donated goods.
  • Share this campaign!
Thank you for your support!

story:
Why is it important to get young people to UNCSW?

 

For two weeks each year around International Women’s Day on March 8th, thousands of delegates gather at the United Nations in New York City for the Commission on the Status of Women. Faith based organizations such as the Anglican Church send delegates to participate in the Commission.

For anyone who is interested in the important ministry of gender justice, this is the place to learn, connect and engage. Right now in the Church, we need young feminists who have an interest in gender justice to be able to come to UNCSW.

But for young people in Canada, the cost of a week or more in New York City is too high. Right now there is no dedicated funding at any level in our Church for gender justice ministry or UNCSW in particular and so the only way to help young people get there, is for us to do our own fundraising.

The UN Commission on the Status of Women is a wonderful opportunity to support and empower young feminists in the Church. We need your financial gift to help get there.

Women's organizations and faith leaders for gender justice and endorse our project:

The Anglican Church Women of the Diocese of New Westminster are contributing up to $10,000 towards the travel costs for delegates from that diocese.

 

"It is essential that Anglican youth and young adults are enabled to speak into processes and decision-making that will have a significant impact on their lives and well-being, and to bring the formative values of their faith to a broader arena. Young people are under multiple pressures the world over but have the potential to bring hope and energy to transforming those things which would thwart their own human flourishing and the thriving of others - especially where they are given opportunities to advocate, network and learn from others."

- The Rev. Terrie Robinson Director for Women in Church & Society

Anglican Communion Office, London, UK

 

"I think it is vital that young women from our diocese attend the UN Commission on the Status of Women, as they will carry that experience into all their future church leadership, as clergy and laity.  I know my early formation with the World Council of Churches and Ecumenical Forum study tours widened my vision of the Church and shaped a lifelong passion for world-wide social and justice issues.  This kind of participation and exposure is essential to the health of the local Church, especially with living out our fourth Mark of Mission: To transform unjust structures of society, to challenge violence of every kind and pursue peace and reconciliation."

- The Rev. Dr. Lynne McNaughton, Priest, St. Clements, North Vancouver,

Deputy Prolocutor, Anglican Church of Canada

 

What is the experience of UNCSW like?

Going to UNCSW is a different experience for each participant. There is so much gender justice work going on all at once, including:

  • Talks, panels and presentations hosted by different governments and NGOs.
  • Visits to national missions to the UN to discuss issues relevant to each national context.
  • Daily worship hosted by our umbrella group, Ecumenical Women.
  • Strategy meetings about how we can advocate for the issues that need more attention.
  • Daily briefings on the progress of the agreed conclusions - the UN document which is negotiated between governments on the priority theme.
  • Opportunities to meet in regional and special interest groups.
  • Receptions and cultural presentations
  • Visits to the UN headquarters.

All of this focuses around a different theme each year which runs like a thread through all these aspects of UNCSW. This year the theme is 'Women's Economic Empowerment in the Changing World of Work.'

The UN Working Group on Girls holds an orientation and a youth forum to ensure that young people make the most of their time at CSW. Young delegates from different countries and youth organizations take part in crafting their own statement on the year's theme.

Anglicans also get together regularly to connect with others from across the Communion and with our ecumenical partners. We worship together, share meals, tell stories of our home Churches and countries and write statements together to share our experience with the rest of the Anglican Communion. The Canadian Anglican group has always been very active and it is always exciting to orient new people to this gender justice work.

 

Caitlin's Story about Alice

Alice has been doing gender justice work in the Church for decades, her whole career in ministry really. She was one of the first women to serve as a parish priest in the Anglican Church of Canada; she was in Beijing in 1995 for the fourth World Conference on Women; she has been to meetings of the Anglican Consultative Council as a part of the International Anglican Women's Network; she has been to UNCSW countless times.

I still remember my first conversation with Alice, in 2011 before my first time going to the UN Commission on the Status of Women. She was excited to have a young person (well Church young) as a part of their delegation - like really excited, giddy really. You see, Alice is in her 80s and she wants to make sure that this ministry she has been called to is carried on by younger generations. From this first conversation, her enthusiasm and passion for this ministry was catching. My first experience of UNCSW was a whirlwind, and my main take away was that this amazing experience needed to be shared. That it is important for us to lift as we climb. I want to make this opportunity more accessible, especially for young people.

"Change is slow,

but if we don't work for change

our granddaughters will have to." - The Rev. Canon Alice Medcof

 

Here is what some previous participants have to say:

"A few words I can use to describe the entire experience are inspirational, educational and thought provoking...Over the course of the week I had the opportunity to be a part of two different statement writings...It was important, useful and necessary to have the opportunity to bring up our ideas and points of view separate from the work being done by adult delegates.  I personally was pleased to have the opportunity to address the current situation of the LGBTQ community (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans* and Queer) in Canada and specifically that of Trans* women."

- Evie Byrne, youth participant in UNCSW58, 2014

"A lasting impression of attending the Commission on the Status of Women meetings for the first time is of tears...... lots of tears... pouring freely down my cheeks... Tears of gratitude to be able to participate in something I had dreamed of for years; tears of sadness at the stories and statistics of women's plight around the world, one heard in every meeting and conversation; tears of wonder at the thousands of people from all parts of the globe that cared, that came, that advocated, that dared to believe it could be different, that knew that while some progress had been made there was still a long way to go and were committed to go the distance." - Ellen Duffield, participant in UNCSW58, 2014

 

How will your financial gift help?

The group includes people from the Diocese of New Westminster and the Diocese of Niagara. We will be using the money from this campaign to pay for rooms at the YMCA near the UN as well as our food and some incidental costs like the shuttle from the airport and registration fees for events. We also have separate funding for our travel costs for each group, since these amounts are quite different for those from each diocese. This is a "flexible funding" project so whatever amount we raise will go to increase the quality and accessibility of the trip. Each participant will also be contributing to the total cost; each dollar we raise will decrease the cost to participants and make it easier for them to participate.

$8550 CAD  ($6,384 USD)  Accommodations for 12 at the YMCA for 7 nights      

$4200 CAD  Food and Incidental Costs, $50/day/person for 12 people for 7 days

$1250 CAD   Emergency Fund and Funding Campaign Fees

Total Expenses = $14,000 CAD

Canadian contributors giving $20 or more will receive an official charitable donation receipt for tax purposes through the Anglican Diocese of New Westminster.

 

Who are we & Why do we want to go?

 

"In the Old Testament there are so many examples of empowered women who challenge the standards of their society and advocate for change. As we establish these female role models, I encourage them to transfer this learning and make connections with modern day women. It is so important for young girls to be able to look and see themselves in different female leaders." - Alicia Armstrong

 

"I am the chair of a committee to organise an event for our leadership class. I’m the only female in the group and it’s hard to be taken seriously and to be seen as a leader. I hope that in the future women will not be subjected sexism in schools and in their workplace." - Clare Urquhart

"I am keen to be more involved in economic justice and the health and wellbeing and rights of women and children, The wide scope of the UNCSW will give me an opportunity to network and learn what is happening in other parts of the world. I’m looking forward to learning more about advocacy, how I can assist and how I can help motivate and encourage others to be active and involved." - The Rev. Karen Urquhart

 

"I believe in an ever-loving God who is pure goodness and wants peace and love for all of His children, and I believe that Feminism is a movement which is important to that being lived out in the world. However, I am still struggling to fully understand what that entails for me, and how to tie those together into the way that I live my life and the career that I choose to pursue. I would like to attend the UNCSW61 because I would like to learn more about the inter-connectedness of my faith and my politics, and how to enact that in my life." - Sierra Robertson-Roper

 

"We learn about economy in socials class but I have noticed the spotlight is always on the men. They did everything. I honestly believe it would be amazing if we could start getting more women in the spotlight." - Aili Peterson McIntyre

 

"I am very excited about the possibility of being a part of this group with my daughter – to allow her to have the opportunity to begin to think about women’s role in economy, and in the work place. I worry that there is a complacency in younger women today. I worry that they are not investing in feminist discourse or women’s equality. I want to be a part of these conversations with her and to encourage her to think about women and their place as equal participants in the economic world." - The Rev. Marnie Peterson

 

"What I care most about, what makes me passionate when it comes to feminism, women's rights, and gender equality, is the “traditional” women's roles and the devaluing of the people who do them regardless of gender.  The fact that those jobs are far more important than society seems to realize and that recognition of that fact is needed." - Willow Martin Seedhouse

 

"My “social justice journey”, as I like to call it,  first started when I was twelve. At this age, I started to attend youth synod and have gone for four years since then. Throughout my four years at youth synod, I have learned about many social justice issues, from local to worldwide...I want to educate myself as much as possible about these issues so that I can do everything I can in my local community to help with them." - Ceilidh Gibson

 

"The opportunity to go to the UN not only enables us to build solidarity and support networks with people from around the world, but to also build tools that we bring back to our home communities.  Religious communities play a particularly intimate role in the lives of women, and their lived experiences of both oppression and justice.  Participating in the Anglican delegation, committed to accountability and social justice, will shape these resources and tools to the needs of the church.  It also helps to build bridges between the church and the struggles of people in the church that sometimes go unrecognized as ‘church’ issues." - Jessi Taylor

 

"It is my intention that, by participating in UNCSW61, I will be able to further educate myself, as well as equip myself with the tools to continue to effectively advocate for women’s economic struggles back at home. Across the globe, women must be advocated for, and the state of our rights must change. "  - Sasha Soden

 

"I believe investing in women’s economic empowerment moves us towards gender equality, poverty eradication and inclusive economic growth...As a sustainable designer I am particularly interested in the designing of systems which could help woman’s economic empowerment in the workplace." - Sarah Lloyd

 

"I want to attend the UN Conference on the Status of Women to learn. It would be an incredible opportunity to be able to dig deep into some of the issues facing women at home and abroad. I would like to be able to better understand how I can help advocate for and practice gender equality, as well as better understand issues particularly around culture and working women." - Jacob Muir

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially we still need your help. Please:

  • Pray for the young people and project team who are committing themselves to work for gender justice.
  • Share this campaign with contacts and friends through e-mail, word of mouth and social media.
  • Keep up to date on our time at the UN and our work for gender justice on the IAWN Canada blog. (Where you can also subscribe to our email list for updates throughout the year and for future CSW news.)

Receptions and cultural presentations
Visits to the UN headquarters.

All of this focuses around a different theme each year which runs like a thread through all these aspects of UNCSW. This year the theme is 'Women's Economic Empowerment in the Changing World of Work.'
The UN Working Group on Girls holds an orientation and a youth forum to ensure that young people make the most of their time at CSW. Young delegates from different countries and youth organizations take part in crafting their own statement on the year's theme.
Anglicans also get together regularly to connect with others from across the Communion and with our ecumenical partners. We worship together, share meals, tell stories of our home Churches and countries and write statements together to share our experience with the rest of the Anglican Communion. The Canadian Anglican group has always been very active and it is always exciting to orient new people to this gender justice work.
 
Caitlin's Story about Alice
Alice has been doing gender justice work in the Church for decades, her whole career in ministry really. She was one of the first women to serve as a parish priest in the Anglican Church of Canada; she was in Beijing in 1995 for the fourth World Conference on Women; she has been to meetings of the Anglican Consultative Council as a part of the International Anglican Women's Network; she has been to UNCSW countless times.

I still remember my first conversation with Alice, in 2011 before my first time going to the UN Commission on the Status of Women. She was excited to have a young person (well Church young) as a part of their delegation - like really excited, giddy really. You see, Alice is in her 80s and she wants to make sure that this ministry she has been called to is carried on by younger generations. From this first conversation, her enthusiasm and passion for this ministry was catching. My first experience of UNCSW was a whirlwind, and my main take away was that this amazing experience needed to be shared. That it is important for us to lift as we climb. I want to make this opportunity more accessible, especially for young people.
"Change is slow,
but if we don't work for change
our granddaughters will have to." - The Rev. Canon Alice Medcof
 
Here is what some previous participants have to say:

"A few words I can use to describe the entire experience are inspirational, educational and thought provoking...Over the course of the week I had the opportunity to be a part of two different statement writings...It was important, useful and necessary to have the opportunity to bring up our ideas and points of view separate from the work being done by adult delegates.  I personally was pleased to have the opportunity to address the current situation of the LGBTQ community (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans* and Queer) in Canada and specifically that of Trans* women."
- Evie Byrne, youth participant in UNCSW58, 2014

"A lasting impression of attending the Commission on the Status of Women meetings for the first time is of tears...... lots of tears... pouring freely down my cheeks... Tears of gratitude to be able to participate in something I had dreamed of for years; tears of sadness at the stories and statistics of women's plight around the world, one heard in every meeting and conversation; tears of wonder at the thousands of people from all parts of the globe that cared, that came, that advocated, that dared to believe it could be different, that knew that while some progress had been made there was still a long way to go and were committed to go the distance." - Ellen Duffield, participant in UNCSW58, 2014
 
How will your financial gift help?
The group includes people from the Diocese of New Westminster and the Diocese of Niagara. We will be using the money from this campaign to pay for rooms at the YMCA near the UN as well as our food and some incidental costs like the shuttle from the airport and registration fees for events. We also have separate funding for our travel costs for each group, since these amounts are quite different for those from each diocese. This is a "flexible funding" project so whatever amount we raise will go to increase the quality and accessibility of the trip. Each participant will also be contributing to the total cost; each dollar we raise will decrease the cost to participants and make it easier for them to participate.
$8550 CAD  ($6,384 USD)  Accommodations for 12 at the YMCA for 7 nights      
$4200 CAD  Food and Incidental Costs, $50/day/person for 12 people for 7 days
$1250 CAD   Emergency Fund and Funding Campaign Fees
Total Expenses = $14,000 CAD
Canadian contributors giving $20 or more will receive an official charitable donation receipt for tax purposes through the Anglican Diocese of New Westminster.
 
Who are we & Why do we want to go?
 

"In the Old Testament there are so many examples of empowered women who challenge the standards of their society and advocate for change. As we establish these female role models, I encourage them to transfer this learning and make connections with modern day women. It is so important for young girls to be able to look and see themselves in different female leaders." - Alicia Armstrong
 

"I am the chair of a committee to organise an event for our leadership class. I’m the only female in the group and it’s hard to be taken seriously and to be seen as a leader. I hope that in the future women will not be subjected sexism in schools and in their workplace." - Clare Urquhart
"I am keen to be more involved in economic justice and the health and wellbeing and rights of women and children, The wide scope of the UNCSW will give me an opportunity to network and learn what is happening in other parts of the world. I’m looking forward to learning more about advocacy, how I can assist and how I can help motivate and encourage others to be active and involved." - The Rev. Karen Urquhart
 

"I believe in an ever-loving God who is pure goodness and wants peace and love for all of His children, and I believe that Feminism is a movement which is important to that being lived out in the world. However, I am still struggling to fully understand what that entails for me, and how to tie those together into the way that I live my life and the career that I choose to pursue. I would like to attend the UNCSW61 because I would like to learn more about the inter-connectedness of my faith and my politics, and how to enact that in my life." - Sierra Robertson-Roper
 

"We learn about economy in socials class but I have noticed the spotlight is always on the men. They did everything. I honestly believe it would be amazing if we could start getting more women in the spotlight." - Aili Peterson McIntyre
 

"I am very excited about the possibility of being a part of this group with my daughter – to allow her to have the opportunity to begin to think about women’s role in economy, and in the work place. I worry that there is a complacency in younger women today. I worry that they are not investing in feminist discourse or women’s equality. I want to be a part of these conversations with her and to encourage her to think about women and their place as equal participants in the economic world." - The Rev. Marnie Peterson
 

"What I care most about, what makes me passionate when it comes to feminism, women's rights, and gender equality, is the “traditional” women's roles and the devaluing of the people who do them regardless of gender.  The fact that those jobs are far more important than society seems to realize and that recognition of that fact is needed." - Willow Martin Seedhouse
 

"My “social justice journey”, as I like to call it,  first started when I was twelve. At this age, I started to attend youth synod and have gone for four years since then. Throughout my four years at youth synod, I have learned about many social justice issues, from local to worldwide...I want to educate myself as much as possible about these issues so that I can do everything I can in my local community to help with them." - Ceilidh Gibson
 

"The opportunity to go to the UN not only enables us to build solidarity and support networks with people from around the world, but to also build tools that we bring back to our home communities.  Religious communities play a particularly intimate role in the lives of women, and their lived experiences of both oppression and justice.  Participating in the Anglican delegation, committed to accountability and social justice, will shape these resources and tools to the needs of the church.  It also helps to build bridges between the church and the struggles of people in the church that sometimes go unrecognized as ‘church’ issues." - Jessi Taylor
 

"It is my intention that, by participating in UNCSW61, I will be able to further educate myself, as well as equip myself with the tools to continue to effectively advocate for women’s economic struggles back at home. Across the globe, women must be advocated for, and the state of our rights must change. "  - Sasha Soden
 

"I believe investing in women’s economic empowerment moves us towards gender equality, poverty eradication and inclusive economic growth...As a sustainable designer I am particularly interested in the designing of systems which could help woman’s economic empowerment in the workplace." - Sarah Lloyd
 

"I want to attend the UN Conference on the Status of Women to learn. It would be an incredible opportunity to be able to dig deep into some of the issues facing women at home and abroad. I would like to be able to better understand how I can help advocate for and practice gender equality, as well as better understand issues particularly around culture and working women." - Jacob Muir
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially we still need your help. Please:

Pray for the young people and project team who are committing themselves to work for gender justice.
Share this campaign with contacts and friends through e-mail, word of mouth and social media.
Keep up to date on our time at the UN and our work for gender justice on the IAWN Canada blog. (Where you can also subscribe to our email list for updates throughout the year and for future CSW news.)

story:
Sing for the Children â€“ The Foundation 

Sing for the Children is a Foundation with a little twist on saying No to Human Traffickingâ€¦ The Foundation Believes; One cannot reach their dreams without creating Positive Words of Thoughts and Actions, along with Conviction of Faith and Pray, which the foundation will do in order to win the battle against of Human Trafficking. 

 

Our goal is to build education programs all over the world, starting in India.  With education, children will be able to say No to Strangers who offer them a job to help support their family.   This is how children become victims of human trafficking, because they feel they do not have a way out and want to help their families by providing money for food and clothing.  Unfortunately, once the child is taken away from their families, they are then forced into child labor, sex slavery and illegal adoptions, all part of a business that is growing worldwide profiting 32 Billion Dollars per year!

 

We hope that you will support the foundation created by International Singer â€“ Anju Indian Princess!  Anju was once a victim of Human Trafficking, but one of the Lucky ones!   She was found and rescued at the age of 4, and then later adopted into a wonderful Christian Missionary Family!   Anju will be reuniting with her birth family in India soon, which will also be part of the documentary being filmed in India. 

She was blessed with an education and now wants to help others by offering them the same opportunities she was offered.  She is helping by being a voice for the children and she asks you to help not just by speaking, but creating that positive energy making a Joyful Noise to â€œSing for the Childrenâ€ ~ Thank You! 

Another Way to show your support is to LIKE US ON FACEBOOK @ http://www.facebook.com/singforthechildren   ~

Get This Lovely T-shirt for your contribution of $25 ~

story:
Dear friends and family, near and far,

As some of you may know, this fall I traveled to South Africa for one of our Virgin Unite Connection Trips which exposes our Community of supporters to some of the frontline organizations we work with.

Little did I know when I left New York on Sunday, September 29th, what a truly impactful trip this would be for me, both personally and professionally, and I would like to tell you the story of a man I had the absolute pleasure of meeting, and who we have the opportunity to make a significant and lasting impact for.

I will forever be grateful for the opportunity to meet and get to know one of the Branson Centre Entrepreneurs, Aaron Langa, founder, owner, designer and manufacturer of ZASUN, whose generosity of time, resources and spirit continues to astound me. Aaron shared with me Mongezi Khambule’s story, and from his first words, it was clear that Aaron was desperate to help his friend in any way he could, determined to find a way to get Mongezi a new wheelchair.

So please – take a moment to meet Mongezi, a wonderful man who I met on my last day in Johannesburg, and I hope you can find it in your hearts to contribute to what will make such a profound impact for him, and subsequently his community – a new, fully functioning and supportive wheelchair.  It may sound cliché, but truly every little bit helps and for the price of that latte, new pair of shoesor night out on the town, together we can truly make a lasting difference in this man’s life. I can assure you the effort will not go unnoticed or wasted, for Mongezi and Aaron will continue to improve the lives of their community together; any effort and resources we provide will be amplified tenfold upon arrival in South Africa.

Mongezi Khambule was born March 3rd, 1977 in the Eastern Cape of South Africa.  Though his parents did not pass away until 2000 and 2001, mother and father respectively, Mongezi was raised by his aunt who moved him to Johannesburg in 1986.

At only 22 years old, when most of us feel we are just beginning, Mongezi’s life was changed forever when he was accidently shot in the neck, restricting him to a wheelchai, unable to walk.

Just five years later, in 2004, the unthinkable happened – already constrained to wheelchair, Mongezi was shot again by people who broke into his flat and robbed him. They took everything he had – disability money and that which he’d managed to save from his businesses of selling sweets and snacks, and fixing computers.

An operation in 2005 to removethe bullets from his sacrum left him unable to bend at the waist, so to this day, he is restricted to lying flat.  That same year, Mongezi developed sores on his feet, causing him excruciating pain, day in and day out.  The doctors he had access to in Johannesburg refused to treat him, believing it could be a lot worse, so he moved to Cape Town in hopes of finding help.  Because he was unable to afford the operation needed, he ended up sleeping on the streets, until, in 2009, four years suffering in pain as his feet rotted before his eyes, a Good Samaritan Doctor finally gave him relief by performing a double amputation of both feet from shin down, at Groote Schuur hospital in Cape Town.

Mongezi’s inability to bend at the waist and sit normally is the reason he needs a special wheelchair that properly supports his body – alleviating undue stress and pressure.  His current wheelchair is falling apart, and as it breaks and becomes less and less reliable, Mongezi becomes more and more dependent on friends to care for him. Without a wheelchair, Mongezi is restricted to his home, and mostly his bed, unable to push himself around due to pressure sores on his elbows from years of use, and stomach cramps from his body’s position.

Mongezi lives in Soweto, a notorious area of Johannesburg where transportation is a challenge for an able bodied person, let alone someone in a wheelchair.  So when he wants to do the things that we take for granted – say go shopping or get a job to support himself – he often struggles because taxis (which come in the form of vans and are the only means of transport in the area) will rarely stop – opting to take the three paying customers for the room that Mongezi in his chair would occupy in the van.

What I haven’t told you yet is that Mongezi is a wiz at fixing computers, and thankfully with mobility in his upper body, he is able to continue using these skills to produce some income for himself. The problem is that he is very often taken advantage of – all too often, in the time it takes him to get himself into his wheelchair, his client has collected their computer and left without paying him for his services.

Mongezi is supported by the generous aid and assistance of his community, in particular Aaron Langa and his wife Zandi, who out of the kindness of their hearts, help Mongezi with food and support his business.  Aaron has even offered to have Mongezi work out of their home so to help enforce payment.  In return for the Langa’s kindness, Mongezi ensures Aaron’s computer is running smoothly – which is key for the success of his business, ZASUN. 

Apart from having a home of his own, Mongezi has big dreams for his community – he wishes to build a rehabilitation center which would provide aid and skill training, create jobs and opportunities for other people with disabilities. Mongezi and Aaron estimate that there are over 100 people living in their immediate community with disabilities and there are currently no resources to help and support them.

Mongezi is very likely one of the strongest individuals I have ever met. I have begun to question whether, if I were in his position, I would have a fraction of his strength.  He has faced such adversity, in an unsupportive society, and yet he still greets you, and each and every day, with a warm, friendly and grateful smile. 

The mission is to get Mongezi a new wheelchair – a simple thing, that any of us if we found ourselves in his position would likely take for granted, but for Mongezi Khambule means dignity, independence and the ability to support himself and give back to his community.  Please help us. With gratitude.  

PS - I understand times are tough, and many of us are on tight budgets ourselves, so if you are unable to donate, please consider sharing this with your networks who may be able to.  Thanks!

A summary of where the funds will go is as follows:

Any and all funds raised above the fundraising goal will go towards the maintenance fund, insurance and/or an upgrade to a newer, more supportive chair. 

Mongezi's current wheelchair:



The "new" (refurbished 2nd-hand) power chair that will be fitted with a custom support pad (right), and allow him to move around much easier:

story:
What We’re Up To

Have you ever sat on your couch or in your room and thought about how blessed you really are to have a place to call home? A place that offers shelter and keeps you warm at night? If I’m honest, I don’t do this enough.

 

For those of you who may not know me personally, my name is Tony Goodwin, and I am so excited to be launching a new business that will make giving to the local community a main focus. I come from a strong background in both construction and ministry, and The Masterbuilt Group will combine these in a unique way with two primary initiatives: consulting and outreach.

 

Our primary focus will be consulting with construction professionals needing assistance and training to use online tools to grow their business and become more efficient. The second will be building up local communities in need by giving to organizations who are already doing the incredible work of sharing God’s love with others as they meet real, everyday needs.

 

As a company we will operate on a First Fruits principal that will have us give before we receive. Before any expenses are paid or salaries taken, 10% of gross revenue will be allocated back into the community to build up God’s kingdom and provide help for those in need.

 

This campaign is a display of the mindset we will hold onto as we grow: give first and trust God with the rest. Before we even open our doors, we will give. And your contribution today will help us achieve that goal and go directly to a family in need.

 

The Breakdown

Here’s where your money will be going:

$5,000 - This is the amount The Masterbuilt Group has pledged to Habitat for Humanity as our sponsorship for a build day in Duquesne, PA, on October 28, 2017.

$1,500 - This will help cover start-up costs for the business to make us legit and legal. (domain name, LLC, contract documents, marketing materials, etc.)

$600 - This is Indiegogo’s cut of the contributions to make this campaign happen.

$400 - This will become a starter fund for whatever God leads us to as our next First Fruits initiative.

**Anything in excess of this amount will be given to relief efforts supporting victims of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma.**

 

The Impact

What would it look like if a company gave away more money than it held as profit? How much good could be done in the world with something like that? How many people could be helped?

 

The Masterbuilt Group has committed to increase it’s giving by 1% each year we are in business until we eventually reach the point where we give away more than we keep. Everything we have belongs to God, and this mindset will stay at the forefront of our minds as the company continues to grow and expand.

 

Other Ways You Can Give

If you’re unable to contribute financially, you can do the next best thing!

 

As we acquire more clients, the amount we are able to give as a company will increase more and more. Share this campaign with your Facebook friends. Share it especially with any construction professionals you may know: contractors, carpenters, electricians, plumbers, architects, etc.

 

The more individuals who choose to be generous and the more construction professionals who choose to become clients, the more God may choose to move through The Masterbuilt Group to touch those lives in need.

 

However you choose to give, thank you for being a part of this journey with us!

story:
Over the Christmas holidays I will be volunteering for a Norwegian NGO and working in a refugee camp in Greece. The NGO is called Drop in the Ocean (https://www.drapenihavet.no/en/home/) and the camp is located just outside Athens. It is one of the largest refugee camps in Greece and “A Drop in the Ocean” organizes a number of activities for the residents. I will most likely be teaching German and English. 

One of their other responsibilities is clothing distribution through their Drop Market, where they “sell” clothing items, shoes and other necessities to refugees in the camp. At the Market, they use their own crypto currency – “Drops” – that makes it possible for the refugees to shop the same way as in a normal store, and ensure they supply aid with dignity. 

I would like to raise funds to take with me to Greece - it is great if donated money is spent directly in Greece in order to support their local economy . Also, that way I can use the money exactly for what is needed at the time in the camp (e.g. underwear, winter shoes etc.)
 

I feel very strongly about this cause as I am myself the child of refugees who fled then Communist Czechoslovakia and thanks to that I had a very privileged life and therefore would like to give back to people who deserve the same opportunities I had.
story_txt: Over the Christmas holidays I will be volunteering for a Norwegian NGO and working in a refugee camp in Greece. The NGO is called Drop in the Ocean (https://www.drapenihavet.no/en/home/) and the camp is located just outside Athens. It is one of the largest refugee camps in Greece and “A Drop in the Ocean” organizes a number of activities for the residents. I will most likely be teaching German and English. One of their other responsibilities is clothing distribution through their Drop Market, where they “sell” clothing items, shoes and other necessities to refugees in the camp. At the Market, they use their own crypto currency – “Drops” – that makes it possible for the refugees to shop the same way as in a normal store, and ensure they supply aid with dignity. I would like to raise funds to take with me to Greece - it is great if donated money is spent directly in Greece in order to support their local economy . Also, that way I can use the money exactly for what is needed at the time in the camp (e.g. underwear, winter shoes etc.) I feel very strongly about this cause as I am myself the child of refugees who fled then Communist Czechoslovakia and thanks to that I had a very privileged life and therefore would like to give back to people who deserve the same opportunities I had.

story:
I am mad as hell at the NFL and I can't take it anymore.  So I was hoping we could all do something about it.  On November 19th, Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch was fined $100,000 by the NFL for not TALKING to the media.  In the meantime, the NFL, and Roger Goodell in particular, continues to ignore the health of his employees (concussions), their wives (Ray Rice) and their children (Adrian Peterson (come on, we all know the suspension is to protect Goodell)). So help me make a point by helping raise $100,000 for kids in the Seattle (Where Lynch works), Oakland (Where Lynch is from) and Houston (Where Adrian Peterson beat his son (In case you forgot)) areas.

Let me be clear, I am a Packer fan that went to UCLA, so I got no love for a football player from Cal who went to play for the Seahawks (with a coach I despise).  But, Marshawn seems like a good human being. Did you all see this?   It is ridiculous that he loses $100k while the rest of this insanity is going on.   I will start by donating the equivalent of what I typically pay for tickets for my son and I to go to a Packer game every year.  We didn't go this year.  Although, I love the Pack, the NFL only got my money for royalties on a Jordy Nelson jersey for my son, because Jordy is the MAN and I can't disappoint my son. 

All proceeds will be split evenly between:

Treehouse (Seattle)

Calico Center (Oakland)

Child Advocates (Houston)

A note to Lynch:  Hey, Marshawn, if you are listening and since you don't seem to be very happy with Seattle, it would be great to see you in Green Bay next year.  I would love to see you wrecking shop with A Rod and Eddie Lacy.  Could be best two back combo in history!  If you make it happen, first beer and brat is on me.

story:
Կարդալ հայերենով

Читать на русском

Join us in providing a safe sanctuary for Syrian refugees in Armenia to raise      their children and heal from the trauma of war.

Cause

The war in Syria – now in its 5th year – has unleashed the worst humanitarian crisis of our time, leaving millions of innocent citizens homeless and vulnerable.

According to the UNHCR, over 15,000 Syrian refugees have found refuge in Armenia since the start of the Syrian war in 2011. Silver lining -- due to Armenia’s urban infrastructure, Syrian refugees in Armenia are urban refugees and not living in tent cities.

Who We Are
#RootsForRefugees is a nonprofit campaign initiated by the Armenian Redwood Project to provide subsidized rent to Syrian refugee households in Armenia.  The campaign has partnered with Oxfam Armenia and the Syrian Armenian Relief Fund to augment rent subsidy vouchers to Syrian Refugees in 2015.

#RootsForRefugees builds on best practices and is a continuation of UNHCR’s rent subsidy program that started in 2014 in Armenia, which benefited hundreds of families. Our partnership was launched in February 2015 in Yerevan through the same operating partner UNHCR utilized: Mission Armenia NGO.

Impact

Our aim is to augment the absorptive capacity in Armenia to benefit newly arriving refugees, and other vulnerable families who have taken refuge in Armenia. The campaign will allow vulnerable refugees to have a safe sanctuary to raise children.  It also provides a safe place to start the long overdue healing from the traumas of war.


We firmly believe that investments in rent subsidies for children & families is a sustainable approach in the long-run; even though it will require continued charitable giving by private donors and its International partners until these families make adjustments in their lives.


How it Works

Your charitable donation (minus the Indiegogo processing fees) will directly go into funding the rent of refugee families.

For planning purposes we have calculated that rent subsidies will cost $200 per month, per household on average. That is about $6.6/day. 

Subsidy rates will fluctuate, as certain households will receive certain rent subsidies based on their immediate family circumstances and according to intake criteria set up by our partner Oxfam in the field.  It is also important to note that $220,000 was raised offline at the beginning of the year from a combination of grants from Oxfam, Syrian Armenian Relief Fund and various small family foundations. The #RootsForRefugees campaign goal of $30,000 will complete the collective commitment of $250,000 made with our partners for Syria’s refugees in Armenia in 2015. That said, donations raised in this online campaign are being leveraged 1:7 (if we consider the $220,000 that were raised already). This also means that the program is already operational and we’re 99 % sure it will happen in 2015!



Frequently Asked Questions

Are you a non-profit?  Can I write-off my contribution with my taxes?

Yes, ANMF Inc. [one of the backers of ArmenianRedwoodProject] is registered as a public 501(c) (3) nonprofit. Contributions to ANMF Inc. are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

If you are a US tax-payer looking to make a tax deductible donation of $75 or more and you are receiving a gift, this will constitute a quid pro quo contribution. We have estimated that the value of each of our gifts will constitute 20% of the value of your donation. Per IRS guidelines, a charitable organization must provide a written disclosure to donors of a quid pro quo contribution in excess of $75 during its solicitation. A quid pro quo contribution is a payment made to a charity by a donor partly as a contribution and partly for goods or services provided to the donor by the charity. 

How can I get a tax deductible receipt?

When you contribute, you will receive an email from FirstGiving (Indiegogo’s nonprofit payments processor) confirming your contribution.  This email receipt can be used for tax deductible purposes. 

How will the funds be used?

Our approximate cost breakdown is as follows. Note: the costs below do not account for all our staff costs as those have been already funded. The costs below are to the best of our knowledge given our experience to-date.  Affordable housing subsidy economics are not always as simple as this chart makes it seem, but you get the idea.






Where are Syrian Refugees renting houses?

Unlike large refugee "tent cities" in other host countries, Yerevan the capital of Armenia has hosted the majority of Syria.  There are some refugees that are choosing to live in other cities in Armenia as well.  The program does not put any constraints on the beneficiaries. And since most Syrian refugees in Armenia are choosing to live in urban settings, they are finding rental units that are suitable to their particular conditions (i.e. work, school, budget, household size and public transport).


If major development organizations are already supporting you, why should I help?

To date, we’ve been privileged to have the support of many generous individuals and foundations. We have also partnered with Oxfam in Armenia and agreed to match part of the cost of the rent subsidy program to Syrian refugees in Armenia.

Our offline capital campaign in the last 6 months has allowed us to jump start the program starting February 2015. To finish our commitment for the 2015 rent subsidy program, we need to raise the last $30,000 from friends & community members.

What happens when we surpass our goal of $30,000?

Beyond the $30,000 mark, all donations, regardless of the amount, will help further our mission and allow us to reach more refugees. And because all gifts are matched by our existing donors and partners, your support is leveraged for greater impact.

While we have a goal for the 2015 program of $30,000, almost half of this year has already elapsed, and while we have already launched the program in early February 2015 (i.e families are already benefiting) we are thinking about 2016 which is approaching quickly.

In the case of a pleasant surprise, where our fundraising goal is stretched beyond the $50,000 mark, we will also consider allocating the extra funds to extend the program into the 2016 calendar year.

Please note that even if (somewhat miraculously) a meaningful political settlement and ceasefire inside Syria are achieved, Syrian refugees are likely to remain where they are for many years; the crisis therefore requires long-term planning on the part of refugee host governments in collaboration with global civil society and multinational institutions.

Can I donate from outside the USA?

Absolutely! Indiegogo only accepts international credit cards, not bank or debit cards. Unfortunately we can’t accept PayPal, so the way to donate internationally is with a credit card.

Can I send in a donation via check/Money order ?

Yes, you can mail your donation to the following :

Make checks out to: ANMF Inc.

Address: 12400 Ventura Boulevard # 261, Studio City, CA 91604

Large Contributions - How can I make a contribution over $10,000?

The nonprofit payment processor (FirstGiving) that is handling the transactions for this campaign is able to accept direct wire transfers for contributions of $10,000 or more. If you are interested in making a large contribution through a wire transfer to FirstGiving, please contact us at armenianredwoodproject@gmail.com. We’ll connect you with a specialist at Indiegogo who will assist you with the contribution transfer process.

I have more questions. Who do I ask?

Please use the contact form to ask your question. We’ll get back to you as soon as we can.                     

       _____________________________________________________________________

    

For your contribution:                                                                

         

Artist Ashot Harutyunuan                                        

Cavalier At Work Oil on canvas, 47" x 47"  (2013) 

     

Artist Ashot Harutyunuan  

The City Oil on Canvas, 35" X 27"  (2010)

    

Artist Zadik Zadikian

Mariam and Jesus 16" x 20" LE silk-screen print                

                                                                                                                                                    ____________________________________________________________________________


Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you cannot donate, please spread the word.  Share this link inviting friends to join our campaign. Let friends know it's worthwhile supporting #RootsForRefugees

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools, and send this out to everyone you know, via Facebook, Twitter, and email. Let's go viral!

  • Use the hashtag #RootsForRefugees
  • If you read this far, thank you for caring!

story:
Hello everyone! 

My name is Nadja Aronchik and I am part of the NKO Resurs LGBTKIA Moscow. This year we organize the Fifth LGBTKIAPP+ Family Conference. The conference unites LGBT+ community, LGBT+ families and specialists like psychologists, sexologists, educators etc. who work with vulnerable groups. And we need your help to make it happen!

Why is the conference so important?

Russia is a very homophobic country. In April 2017 the persecution and killings of more that 200 LGBT people in Chechnya were revealed. But that was only the tip of the iceberg. LGBT+ people face discrimination on a daily basis. In 2016/2017 there have been 366 documented cases of violence and hate crimes on grounds of sexual orientation and/or gender identity (SOGI). And the number has only risen since the “aniti-propaganda-law” has been passed in 2013.

Our conference is a unique platform for an exchange of unbiased information between specialists of helping professions (psychologists, educators, pedagoges etc.). It is the only platform in the CIS that addresses the problem of homo-, bi- and transphobia among psychologists and provides guidelines on working with vulnerable groups. The conference also helps LGBT+ connect and experience the support from others. 

 

What have we done so far?

For the past five years we have worked closely with the LGBT+ community. Every month we held 40 different events (support groups, language courses, movie screenings, educational seminars, supervisions etc.). We already published four collections of articles based on the seminars of the past conferences and held two festivals for family equality.

 

And we won’t stop. Last year several of our volunteers and guests were attacked by homophobes after the second day of the conference. We had to postpone the third day but we still made it happen. The support of the LGBT+ community and our colleagues has shown us how important this event is.

The LGBTKIAPP+ Family Conference is a unique opportunity for experts and the community to meet. In 2017 we had about 400 participants. Among them 200 specialists and 35 speakers, like the Italian PhD psychologist, sexologist, intersex-researcher Dr. Massimo Di Grazia and the founder and director of Swiss Rainbow Families Association Maria von Känel.

 

How can you help?

To provide this one of a kind platform for exchange, education and support we need money. We are a volunteer-based organisation, so we can cover a lot of preparations. We hope to invite international experts this year as well. With the popularity of the conference rising we await 500 participants this year.

What we need to cover is

Security (1000 Euro), articles collection with the results of the conference (printing, binding, copywriting) (2000), salaries (organizers, manager, speaker) (3000), travel and accommodation expenses for speakers (1500), video and after-report of the sessions (800), food and catering (700), info material for participants (500), taxes (500)

All costs to indiegogo and taxes for money transfer considered, around 20% of the collected money gets lost. That would be around 2000 Euro that we need to add to our sum.

Which makes a total of 12 000 Euro.

 

We already found a great place that will provide us rooms for those 3 days FOR FREE. We also talked to several speakers who agreed to participate pro bono. We minimized all our expenses and used our resources to make the conference happen with only the 10 000 Euro (usually you need at least 50 000 for a three day long conference!).

Now we need your help to continue support people in Russia. Help us share the idea of stereotype-free counselling and respect to Human Rights.

If you can't contribute yourself,  please share this projects with your friends, colleagues or on social media. We appreciate any kind of support!

Help us provide this important platform for the LGBT+ community and people of helping professionals!

 

Further Information

You can check out our work on our webside: http://resourcerus.org/en/home/

A post-release of the last years conference you can check out here: http://resourcerus.org/en/conference-2017/

If you have any questions regarding this project, feel free to email us at n.arontschik@gmail.com

story:
We've been busy.

2012 was our most active year ever! Members of Bay Area Intactivists held over twenty protests and demonstrations, staffed booths at six street fairs, participated in five baby fairs, organized contingents in two GLBT Pride parades, built two memorial art installations, held Critical Integrity bike rides nearly every month, and worked with Glen Callender to make "The Revolution Will Not Be Circumcised" a success during its six-show run in San Francisco!

Big things are coming.

We are energized and actively working on even more great events for 2013! Bay Area Intactivists is already registered to march in the Santa Cruz Pride Parade as well as the San Francisco Pride Parade. There are numerous baby fairs approaching such as the San Francisco Birth & Baby Fair where we will have a booth.

But it doesn't stop there! We are continuously brainstorming about new ways to engage our community in order to raise awareness of the damage caused by circumcision and the human right to genital integrity. Until all individuals are protected from forced genital cutting, our work continues!

But, we need your help.

Even though our dedicated volunteers lend their time and talents, we still incur many expenses such as registration fees, liability insurance, protest signs, and promotional materials. We also must continually replenish our stock of leaflets, stickers, bracelets, and buttons that we distribute at our events.

By making a donation, you can help offset these costs.

Please show your appreciation of our work to end genital mutilation and help ensure that Bay Area Intactivists will continue to be a strong force in the fight for the human right to genital integrity.

Thanks for your support!

But, we need your help.
Even though our dedicated volunteers lend their time and talents, we still incur many expenses such as registration fees, liability insurance, protest signs, and promotional materials. We also must continually replenish our stock of leaflets, stickers, bracelets, and buttons that we distribute at our events.
By making a donation, you can help offset these costs.
Please show your appreciation of our work to end genital mutilation and help ensure that Bay Area Intactivists will continue to be a strong force in the fight for the human right to genital integrity.
Thanks for your support!

story:
Who We Are

We are Friends of Refugees, a certified 501(C)(3) non-profit located in Clarkston, Georgia. Since the 1990s, over 50,000 refugees from all over Asia, Africa, Eastern Europe, and South America have resettled here, hoping to make new lives for themselves and their families. In order to do our part, Friends of Refugees holds the Summer Spectacular, an eight-week long summer camp for the refugee children in our community. The camp is integral because, during the summer months, there is little to no child care. Our all-day camp creates a positive, enriching environment for Clarkston's refugee children to spend their summers.  Last year we had over 109 attend. This year we expect 140! We also take pride in paying our low income student volunteers (older students who have attended camp in previous years) a stipend. This is our way of demonstrating our respect for these young men and women while also showing the importance of a day's work. So, in order to continue and grow Summer Spectacular, we need your help.

What We Do & How You Can Help

Our camp runs June 8th through July 31st. We have a variety of fun and educational activities planned for the kids. These activities, and the supplies we need, are broken down as follows:
Field Trips
This summer we plan on making multiple field trips. As of right now we have trips planned to Stone Mountain Park, the neighborhood pool, The Carter Center and a nearby bowling alley and roller rink. We also have a college visit planned for either Georgia Tech or the University of Georgia. These trips cost us the price of gas, snacks and park entry fees.
Food
We are lucky enough to get 2 full meals a day for each children via a government program. However, we still have to pay out of pocket for all fresh fruit, snacks and drinks.
T shirts
Each year we have a new shirt printed for our students and volunteers. This year's shirt says "Love holds us together." Love is our character education theme for the entire Summer Spectacular. Not only is the theme a powerful one, but this encouraging shared apparel also empowers our campers, volunteers, and staff to be part of something bigger than themselves. We, at Friends of Refugees, hope that love shown through respect, honesty, thankfulness, humility, and service will have a ripple effect in the Clarkston community. We are ordering 200 shirts so, at $5 a shirt, they will cost us $1000.
Stipends
We make a point to pay our student volunteers a small stipend as a thank you for all their hard work. So far we have set aside $1000, however, we will immediately increase the stipend amount if we raise above our fundraising goal.
Soccer Equipment
We're looking for some new soccer equipment that will last, particularly portable goals and new balls.  The world's game is alive in Clarkston as kids from different backgrounds find common ground on the pitch.
Activity Stations
All of our campers receive weekly character education in order to grow spiritually and socially into adults who responsibly contribute to their community, as God created them too do.  We want our kids to have role models and to be role models! In order to do this, we provide craft activities, music instruction, and "Friday Funday" breakout sessions.  Each Friday kids pick their favorite activity, whether it be gardening, soccer, basketball, music, etc, and get to enjoy an entire day of it!  We need supplies for all these activity stations. 

The Impact

"You’re not just taking care of the kids for a couple of hours, but you’re sharing your lives with them… you see what goes on behind the scenes … in the kids’ lives"  

-2014 Summer Intern

Temptations are real in Clarkston, an under-served community near Atlanta.  Some refugee youth have unfortunately begun to make trouble by forming rival gangs and by being generally unproductive.  We seek to empower them and their families so that they can thrive, not just survive.

  • Summer Spectacular provides an constructive and fun alternative for youth in refugee families who experience "poverty of opportunity" since, in the summer months, they are sometimes left unattended while their parents work hard at low-wage jobs.  
  • We provide a valuable and affordable summer program for Clarkston’s youth. Many refugee families have multiple children and cannot afford the high costs of child care.
  • Each child receives academic support they desperately need to keep up in school.  
  • Each young person at Summer Spectacular makes relationships, visits places in Atlanta, and receives loving care that they otherwise may not. 
  • Last year, 117 campers and counselors heard messages of hope and encouragement from volunteers and staff from local churches and colleges.
  • In 2014, 27 high school students received a stipend for their hard work, 5 of whom then deposited it into their first bank account!
  • 2015 will be our 15th year of Summer Spectacular!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Like us on Facebook at 
  • Share the campaign!
  • Volunteer with us!

Thank you!

story:
Summary

Last year's peace deal between the Colombian government and FARC (the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia) brought an end to a war that lasted over 50 years and claimed the lives of more than 200,000 people. Some 25,000 people have been disappeared, and 5.7 million displaced.

The peace deal is now looking distinctly fragile, and with new paramilitary groups flooding into the power vacuum left behind by FARC, violence against human rights defenders and other vulnerable groups has soared. Moreover, there is growing concern that the right wing ‘Democratic Center’ party - which led opposition to the peace deal - will win general elections in March 2018.


In this worrying context, a group of Colombian human rights organizations campaigning for justice in cases of forced disappearance and state crimes have invited Northern Irish groups to visit Colombia and go on a whistlestop three-city tour to help publicise their cause. Eamonn McCann, who has dedicated much of his life to the Bloody Sunday Justice Campaign, will accompany Kate Nash, whose brother William was killed on Bloody Sunday, and Shauna Moreland, whose mother Caroline was disappeared by the IRA, in a visit to the country in early 2018.

There they will attend a series of campaign events with members of MOVICE (the Movement for Victims of State Crimes), the Nydia Erika Foundation, the Mothers of Soacha and the Orlando Flas Bora Collective (spanish), to share experiences, raise public awareness, and help promote justice in Colombia’s delicate post-conflict situation.

From the Colombian side, things are being organized by Alejandra Gaviria (in video clip above), whose father was killed by intelligence services and who is a leading figure in the Movement for Victims of State Crimes. She is joined by, among others, leaders from the ‘Mothers of Soacha’ organization including Luz Marina Bernal, whose son was murdered by the Colombian army and presented as a senior FARC officer supposedly in charge of the organization’s finances. The perpetrators did not realize Fair Leonardo had a severe learning disability and a mental age of approximately seven. Fair was just one of the victims of the 'false positives' scandal, that saw close to 5,000 innocent civilians murdered by state security forces and presented as insurgents in order to win promotions, extra time off and other incentives.

Please help us fight impunity for these terrible crimes!

Trip expenses for Eamonn, Kate and Shauna
    1.    Flights X 3: €3,000
    2.    Internal flights (bogota-medellin-cali-bogota  3 X 3 people) : €1800
    3.    Accomodation: 7 days X 3 = (21 nights X €70): €1470
    4.    Interpreters (X 2): 2 X 5 days: €2,000
    5.    Misc (taxis, meals, travel insurance etc): €1000
    6.    Organization of solidarity events/press conference in Bogotá €2,730


Total: €12,000

What’s more, Luke Holland, who is leading efforts on a documentary project about the trip, has committed €5000 of his own savings to pay for his own travel and the various production costs associated. If and when funding is secured for the documentary, a figure equal to the entire sum raised through this page will be donated to the human rights groups in Colombia.

If you have any queries, please contact Luke at luke@assumenothingmedia.com.
