story:
Our Story

My name is Laura Jennings.  I am a mother of three and wife to Jon who will be traveling to Haiti in November on mission to help rescue, restore and renew homeless families and orphans in Haiti.  Did you know that some of the most vulnerable children in Haiti are orphans without shelter because they are easily targeted by human traffickers?  As a mom, this makes my heart heavy for those precious ones.  Since I am not in a season of life where I can travel to Haiti with Jon to make an impact, I knew I had to do SOMETHING to help...even if it is just from my computer.  That is when I learned that it costs a mere $6000 to build a home for a family in Haiti and I felt compelled to begin this campaign!  If each of us sacrifices a little something, we can make a huge impact for one family in Haiti!

SO, I am asking each of you to consider sacrificing one of the luxuries that we get to enjoy as Americans (such as $25 at Starbucks, $50 for a pedicure, $100 for a fine meal, or $200 for a designer outfit) and make the CHOICE to fore go that luxury this month in order to support this worthy cause.  A little bit of sacrifice by several can mean a new home/shelter/protection for orphans in Haiti!

The Impact

Why homes, you ask? Simple.  The people of Haiti are desperate for homes as thousands live in tents or makeshift shelters. Every time we build a home we:

1.Provide jobs as Haitians do the work to build the homes.
2.Prevent human-trafficking:  the most vulnerable orphans are the main target of traffickers. They are alone, abandoned and desperate. A child now has a place to call home and a community to watch over and protect them.
3.Build healthy families.
4.Restoring their Hope: When we give the key to a home, you can see the tears well-up in the eyes of these families. Most families assumed they would never have access to a home again. I love seeing these families move their belongings from a tent to a home. It's beautiful, it's redemptive, it's justice.

 

What We Need & What You Get

$6000 builds a new home for orphans and families in Haiti. 

 

Your donations go straight to the Help End Local Poverty (H.E.L.P) initiative to end extreme poverty by helping to rescue orphans, restore their hope and renew their communities by building homes.

 

What you get: a feeling of love and satisfaction knowing that by giving up something you enjoy, someone in Haiti will have a roof over their head, making that community stronger and safer for families and especially children.

story:
"I'll die of hunger before I die of this virus." - Sampa Akter

 

 

The spread of COVID-19 has created unparalleled challenges for communities around the world. In Bangladesh, where nearly half of people suffer from malnutrition, it has added oil to the fire.

While the country has made strides in reducing malnutrition since 2000, COVID-19 has decreased accessibility to food due to quarantine and the loss of jobs, and its global hunger index remains at a serious level of GHI 25.8.

Join us to help provide critical nutrition to families in desperate need.

 

Hashi Khushi Fortified Lentil Butter:

Do Good, Eat Well

 

 

Our signature product is our Hashi Khushi Fortified Lentil Butter.

In Bengali, "Hashi Khushi" means "happy and laughing" or "joyful," which is the emotion we hope to create through our tasty snacks and their effects on nutrition.

In order to treat and prevent malnutrition, our lentil butter is specifically designed according to WHO standards and cutting edge research to provide complete nutrition with just 2 sachets a day.

Each sachet is made from freshly roasted lentils, ground puffed rice, nutritious oils, and real milk, and is fortified with 23 micronutrients, including those crucial to child development and pregnancy like calcium and iron.

 

 

When we first developed our lentil butter, I brought some home with me to show friends and family. I was surprised to hear that many of my most active friends enjoyed it before or after workouts, on camping trips, while traveling, or while working long hours in the office or hospital.

This is why we have decided to bring Hashi Khushi to the US, Europe, and other developed markets. Whether you're an athlete, adventurer, or just a busy individual with little time for meal prep, our Lentil Butter is for you.

If you are constantly reaching out for junk food to snack on, or want something really convenient to carry about on your hikes, this is definitely for you.

 

 

Our lentil butter can be consumed directly from the sachet, and is tasty on its own or paired up with fruit or oats!

 

Take it from our endorsers!

Don't just take it from us - hear what our wonderful endorsers have to say about our Hashi Khushi lentil butter.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Frontier Nutrition

 

 

We bring high quality and affordable nutrition to low-income communities around the world.

I moved to Bangladesh for work in 2012 and fell in love with the country, culture, and its people.  I was also socked to witness how poor nutrition led to stunted growth and limited economic opportunities.

As I looked around while enjoying a traditional cup of tea one afternoon, I realized that the options carried by nearby shops were mostly empty calories - delicious and insanely cheap, but mostly a mix of carbs, sugar and salt. They had little nutrition and would barely keep me full, forget about providing the critical nutrients needed by growing children, their mothers, and laborers hard at work. 

This is the reality for millions of families in Bangladesh, where more than half of the children and pregnant women suffer from malnutrition.  There are no affordable or nutritious options.

We started Frontier Nutrition with the mission is to create nutrient-dense, delicious snacks that everyone could afford. We want to remove barriers to proper nutrition.

 

Do Good, Eat Well: What you can do to help

 

Starting from $9, you can send a 3-month supply of fortified lentil butter to families who need it in Bangladesh. Donate more, and you get access to some amazing perks from our implementing partners as well as some delicious lentil butter to try yourself and share with friends!

 

Basha Blanket, available in the Basha Blanket tier

 

Basha Bracelet, available in the Basha Bracelet tier

 

We are working with two incredible organizations in Bangladesh to distribute your donated Lentil Butter. Thrive Global is dedicated to feeding 3,000+ hungry school children, while Friends of Basha provides support, skills development, and employment to women who are survivors of human or sex trafficking. The work they do is truly amazing, and Frontier Nutrition is honored to partner with them.

 

Why we must act NOW to support families in Bangladesh

 

Early this year, COVID-19 swept across the globe, creating tremendous challenges for families around the world.  In Bangladesh, where malnutrition is already rampant, the pandemic has made it even harder for families to afford and find quality, nutritious foods. Many people have lost their jobs, and the spread of the virus in the community and prevalence of multi-family and multi-generational homes means that you put your entire extended family at risk every time you leave the house, even to work or get food.

With this situation at hand, it's nearly impossible for many families to meet their nutritional needs, especially the young children, who need the nutrition the most for proper growth and development.

The first 1000 days of a child's life is very crucial to the trajectory of her life - with the right nutrition, she will be well-equipped with a healthy body to deal with life's challenges.  Without proper nutrition, the body and immune system are at greater risk for contracting the virus and will be less capable at fighting it. For children particularly, poor nutrition has permanent negative consequences for cognitive development, affecting them for the rest of their lives.

Not only that, pregnant also women require tremendous amounts of nutrients to properly nurture their babies before they are born, and poor nutrition among mothers both before and after pregnancy has a significant impact on health outcomes for children.

 

Risks & Challenges

 

Due to COVID-19, delivery may be delayed at your area.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

It's alright if you are not able to donate to this campaign - we understand that everyone's situation is different during this difficult time. Here's what you can do instead:

  • Spread the word among your folks to get the word out, using the hashtags #NutritionWithAMission and #DoGoodEatWell on any social media platform
  • Share our campaign link on all your social media bios or posts
  • Tag us at @hashikhushi_international if you are posting about our product or campaign

Due to COVID-19, delivery may be delayed at your area.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
 
It's alright if you are not able to donate to this campaign - we understand that everyone's situation is different during this difficult time. Here's what you can do instead:

Spread the word among your folks to get the word out, using the hashtags #NutritionWithAMission and #DoGoodEatWell on any social media platform
Share our campaign link on all your social media bios or posts
Tag us at @hashikhushi_international if you are posting about our product or campaign

story:
On 1st October, the Catalonian people will be deciding on their constitutional future. 
As part of this process, the Catalonian Government have invited international observers to come and monitor the vote to ensure it is a fair & well-run referendum, and make reccomendations for future elections as to how democracy can be safeguarded, procedures improved & elections run more efficiently.

Who are English Scots for YES?

We are one of the national campaign groups set up during the 2014 Scottish independence referendum.  We campaigned for an indepenent Scotland during that campaign, and folowing the result, we have worked to persuade our community of fellow English-Scots of the benefits of independence.  

During that campaign, we gathered a large membership of experienced political activists, including a number of serving & retired politicians. Our activists participated in interviews & debates acrosss Scotland and worked with national and international media before the referendum day, and then attened polling places, monitored the voting itself, and attended ballot-authentications & counting across the country.

So are you for or against Catalonian indpendence?

NEITHER.  We are very strictly neutral in this matter.  We support the right of the Catalonian people to have their referendum - and we condemn the Spanish government for their undemocratic actions in the last few days, which are uterly unacceptable...
BUT...
Catalonian independence is a matter for the people of Catalonia, and ONLY them. 
If we are funded to travel to Catalonia to monitor their referendum, we will be strictly neutral third-party observers, working only to monitor the vote to ensure fairness, and provide advice afterwards on how procedures can be improved in any future votes or elections.

What will you be doing
 

We propose to take a small team of our activists (4-5) from Scotland to Barcelona on the 29th or 30th September until the 2nd October; we shall travel around Catalonia on the day of the vote, visiting polling places, interviewing campaigners/activists from both sides of the referendum to get their perspective on any issues or problems, and interacting with polling staff to observe whether there are any issues of conern, and monitor the entire process.
If time is permitting, we shall also take meetings with the "Yes" and "No" campaigns to get their input as well.

Our team will consist of several experienced politicians and activists, including hopefully at least one retired MSP.


Immediately after the vote has concluded, we shall issue a preliminary statement with our thoughts regarding how the vote was handled, any issues that we immediately wish to raise etc.

In the following days, we shall produce a report into the referendum, with any concerns we may have and recommendations for the future.

What do you need?

Money :)
Due to the cost of putting on an Observer Delegation, and given the short time period in which to book flights, hotels etc., we need funds to help run an effective Mission.

Broadly speaking, we need approx. £250-300 per delegate for flights & hotels; another ~£200 for car-rental to move the team around and ~£200-300 to purchase "burner" mobile phones which can be activated on Spanish phone networks for using to document the entire mission;
Our team will upload regular edited & where legally permissable, live-video to social networks to ensure that not only is democracy done, but that it is seen to be done! Due to the slight but feasible risk to personal devices if any form of disturbance breaks out, it would be preferable to purchase cheap devices specifically for the mission, rather than take personal mobiles, tablets etc. to Catalonia.

Our team will be inputting their own funds as well, and no money will be spent on food or drink (which is to say, this is NOT a wee holiday to Barcelona! We will be working or sleeping the entire 2-3 days.)

Isn't this just a wee jolly for you guys to go to Barcelona? Why should I help?

NO, it's not.
See above answer - we shall be working almost the entire time from the moment the plane touches down to when we leave 2-3 days later. Monitoring an election is serious, dificult work. 
We are asking for funding to help ensure we can do a proper, decent job. During the 2014 Scottish Independence Referendum, we were very grateful for the international observers which visited Scotland from across the world, including those from Catalonia.
We think it only right we repay the sentiment by assisting Catalonia in the running of a fair, free & equitible vote.  Self-determination is a sacred right, held by all peoples under the UN Charter Article One, Section Two.  However, democracy does just "happen" - it must be nurtered and safeguarded, monitored and protected by Missions such as this.
Your help will enable us to help the People of Catalonia determine for themselves their own future, free of any intereference.

So what happens if this vote doesn't go ahead, or you can't go?

As you may be aware, elements of the Spanish government have sought to stop this referendum going ahead.  As stated above, our belief in the right to self-determination is absolute, and we believe that ruling regime in Madrid will eventually see this as well. But, if this does not happen, and the Spanish paramilitary "Guardia Civil" do in fact shut own the vote and arrest all those involved, we will not be able to monitor a vote!

If this happens, any funding we raise here will be used to fund "English Scots for YES" activities in Scotland, aimed at pursuing a second referendum for the people of Scotland.
If you are not comfortable with your funding being used for such purposes, please state so in your donation comments; we will endeavour to return such donations to you.
story_txt:
On 1st October, the Catalonian people will be deciding on their constitutional future. As part of this process, the Catalonian Government have invited international observers to come and monitor the vote to ensure it is a fair & well-run referendum, and make reccomendations for future elections as to how democracy can be safeguarded, procedures improved & elections run more efficiently.Who are English Scots for YES?We are one of the national campaign groups set up during the 2014 Scottish independence referendum.  We campaigned for an indepenent Scotland during that campaign, and folowing the result, we have worked to persuade our community of fellow English-Scots of the benefits of independence.  
During that campaign, we gathered a large membership of experienced political activists, including a number of serving & retired politicians. Our activists participated in interviews & debates acrosss Scotland and worked with national and international media before the referendum day, and then attened polling places, monitored the voting itself, and attended ballot-authentications & counting across the country.So are you for or against Catalonian indpendence?NEITHER.  We are very strictly neutral in this matter.  We support the right of the Catalonian people to have their referendum - and we condemn the Spanish government for their undemocratic actions in the last few days, which are uterly unacceptable...BUT...Catalonian independence is a matter for the people of Catalonia, and ONLY them. If we are funded to travel to Catalonia to monitor their referendum, we will be strictly neutral third-party observers, working only to monitor the vote to ensure fairness, and provide advice afterwards on how procedures can be improved in any future votes or elections.What will you be doing 
We propose to take a small team of our activists (4-5) from Scotland to Barcelona on the 29th or 30th September until the 2nd October; we shall travel around Catalonia on the day of the vote, visiting polling places, interviewing campaigners/activists from both sides of the referendum to get their perspective on any issues or problems, and interacting with polling staff to observe whether there are any issues of conern, and monitor the entire process.If time is permitting, we shall also take meetings with the "Yes" and "No" campaigns to get their input as well.Our team will consist of several experienced politicians and activists, including hopefully at least one retired MSP.
Immediately after the vote has concluded, we shall issue a preliminary statement with our thoughts regarding how the vote was handled, any issues that we immediately wish to raise etc.In the following days, we shall produce a report into the referendum, with any concerns we may have and recommendations for the future.What do you need?Money :)Due to the cost of putting on an Observer Delegation, and given the short time period in which to book flights, hotels etc., we need funds to help run an effective Mission.Broadly speaking, we need approx. £250-300 per delegate for flights & hotels; another ~£200 for car-rental to move the team around and ~£200-300 to purchase "burner" mobile phones which can be activated on Spanish phone networks for using to document the entire mission;Our team will upload regular edited & where legally permissable, live-video to social networks to ensure that not only is democracy done, but that it is seen to be done! We will be working or sleeping the entire 2-3 days.)Isn't this just a wee jolly for you guys to go to Barcelona? Why should I help?NO, it's not.See above answer - we shall be working almost the entire time from the moment the plane touches down to when we leave 2-3 days later. Monitoring an election is serious, dificult work. We are asking for funding to help ensure we can do a proper, decent job. During the 2014 Scottish Independence Referendum, we were very grateful for the international observers which visited Scotland from across the world, including those from Catalonia.We think it only right we repay the sentiment by assisting Catalonia in the running of a fair, free & equitible vote.  Self-determination is a sacred right, held by all peoples under the UN Charter Article One, Section Two.  However, democracy does just "happen" - it must be nurtered and safeguarded, monitored and protected by Missions such as this.Your help will enable us to help the People of Catalonia determine for themselves their own future, free of any intereference.So what happens if this vote doesn't go ahead, or you can't go?As you may be aware, elements of the Spanish government have sought to stop this referendum going ahead.  As stated above, our belief in the right to self-determination is absolute, and we believe that ruling regime in Madrid will eventually see this as well. story:
The Project

A former dictator on trial for an estimated 40,000 deaths and other crimes against humanity. Reconciliation and war crimes in Sri Lanka. The need for women to be present at the negotiating table during peace talks in the Democratic Republic of Congo. A breakthrough in peace talks in Colombia.

These are just a few examples of recent stories covered by JusticeInfo.Net, the first bilingual (French and English) media platform that offers systematic coverage, analysis and doc­umentation of international and transi­tional justice around the world. Launched in June 2015 by Fondation Hirondelle, a Swiss NGO that creates or supports independent news media in crisis zones, JusticeInfo.Net provides vital information on these issues to the greater public, and gives a voice to the victims of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and other injustices.


The Challenge

International justice is a phenomenon that is growing in importance. It directly impacts millions of people, and indirectly it im­plicates us all.  While there are many justice processes taking place all over the world today, the populations they are supposed to serve often do not have access to news and information about them. There is a major gap between the people supposedly benefiting from transitional justice, and the actual mechanisms.


Our Solution

To respond to this lack of media coverage on transitional and international justice, and to bridge the divide between populations coming out of war and justice processes, we have created JusticeInfo.Net. It provides independent, comprehensive coverage of these issues to global audiences, as well as to local populations impacted by justice initiatives. It gives a voice to transitional justice actors, communities and victims, and gives priority to the human dimension of transitional justice.  JusticeInfo.Net provides information that is resolutely independent, and that works to bridge the gap between societies and their respective transitional justice systems.

All stories are broadcast online via the JusticeInfo.Net website. These stories are also offered free of charge for any local or other media to pick up and broadcast. JusticeInfo.Net is an educational tool too, offering an interactive calendar, a transitional justice glossary, background portraits and documents that are also free of charge to access and use.


Why We Need You

Your support will help ensure that all transitional justice initiatives and issues are covered around the world, ensuring that populations impacted by justice initiatives have access to the information they need. More specifically, we will be able to increase the number of countries with correspondents working for us around the world, and the number of articles we can translate into French, English and Arabic each day.

At present, countries covered include: Burundi, Cambodia, CAR, Chad/Senegal, Colombia, Côte d’Ivoire, DR-Congo, France, ICC (The Hague), ICTR (Arusha), Israel, Lebanon, Palestinian Territories, Peru, Rwanda, United Kingdom, Sierra Leone, Sri Lanka, Switzerland, Tunisia. Your help will allow us to expand our reach.

We will also use these funds to produce background and educational material for journalists and others who are interested in transitional justice and want to learn more about a given process or situation. We will also be able to include new toolkits and resources, such as the archives from the ICTR-related news agency Hirondelle News (more than 5’000 articles & dispatches since 1997).


The Team

Pierre Hazan, Head of Project

François Sergent, Editor in Chief

Ephrem Rugiririza, Deputy Editor in Chief, French

Julia Crawford, Deputy Editor in Chief, English

Olivier Lechien, Program Manager

JusticeInfo.Net is a partnership with Oxford Transitional Justice Research, which provides expert analysis and opinion pieces on transitional justice.

Thank You!

Your generous support is crucial to expanding news coverage of justice around the world. There are other ways you can help: 

  • Please share this campaign using Indiegogo share tools and on social media
  • Check out and share our website JusticeInfo.Net
